results.content: It's a really, really good course. I learned a lot from it and I believe the things that I learned from this course are something that I can use in the real world. I would also like to commend how the instructor organized the structure of each section of the course. Each section usually starts with a simple explanation, followed by a basic demo, and then it goes on to applying all the concepts in a project. This process made it a lot easier for me to follow and absorb the topics being discussed. Thank you so much! This is a great course and you are an awesome teacher!

results.content: Thank you Brad for this superb course! It is so good that I actually finished it! Too often I've started courses and got bored part way through, or lost interest when I felt I wasn't learning the things I wanted to know. This course is different - it has vastly improved my expertise and skills. I already had some HTML and CSS knowledge when I started, but I was struggling to really 'dial it in'. Things that were previously difficult for me now make sense and I'm feeling so much better. I also love how Brad has packaged in some 'extras' that are super handy to know e.g. Netlify and some basic PHP and JS scripts...these things really make the course 'come to life'. Can't recommend this course enough!

Well, I have discovered a whole new world from this course, as I was a complete beginner taking it at first place.
Brad had gone through the basics and explained them all in a great manner.
You will walk out from this course with decent knowledge regarding HTML & CSS and will definitely be wanting more.

One think I do have to mention is that I wish Brad could keep his HTML file open side by side with the CSS file since sometimes, and I noticed that especially at the last project where things got a little more complicated, there were a lot of different classes so it was kind of though to keep up with all the names those classes were given, so I had to stop the video and make sure I know which div we are currently talking about in the CSS file. 

Beside this, learnt a lot and i'm glad I took this course, thanks Brad!

results.content: Some good content here, but I feel there's a lot in the "code along" sections where he just enters in a chunk of code without explaining what he's doing or why. Really hurts your foundation as you progress further ahead in the course because you've never really had it explained in detail. He just aligns some boxes with Floats or Flex for about 5 minutes and that's your lesson on the Float or Flex model. Then, he goes straight into coding a whole website using methods he never explained in his 5 minute video prior. Really aggravating.

results.content:
As a true beginner, this course was a bit of a double-edged sword. You will definitely learn a lot from this course, and I personally am a fan of Brad's teaching style. I came on with zero coding experience and am leaving quite confident in HTML and CSS and plan on learning JS next from Brad.

Then there's the other side of the sword. If you are a true beginner like me you will have to research a bit outside of the course, which is good in a sense because you won't always be given the answers and have to look on your own. However, at a certain point in the course, Brad goes from explaining things very well to saying things like "Alright we're going to add this..." or "We're going to do this.." without explaining what he's doing or why, and the concepts have not been explained. This comes into play quite a bit in the 'Learning Sass' section, where if you're a complete beginner you will be very lost and mostly everything happening has no prior explanation. 

Overall though, you will get what you came for in the course! It is very well laid out and you will have many great resources to call back onto in the future!
results.content_html:

results.content: I learned a lot, and it at times was like drinking from a fire hose. What I mean by that is that much of the material was easily digested, and there was some that will take more study and practice to feel comfortable when applying it to a project. Something I want to do is break down the more challenging areas into what I would call demonstration areas or templates that could be pulled up when I need them in a project. In other words, I want to create a library of templates that I could drop into a project and make the drop in fully functional with only minor modification. One of those areas is use of Sass to create my personal library of variables that can be applied over and over though possibly with slight modification in each project. Flex is another area where I want to spend more time. All in all, this course measured up to my usual expectations for Brad delivering on the goods! This is one of a number of Brad Traversy courses that I've completed, and I'm never disappointed.Well done!

results.content:
I started off with very little knowledge of HTML and zero knowledge of CSS and this course has helped me tremendously. The format of Brad teaching you (sometimes a little too fast) the fundamentals with sandboxes and then putting them into practice with both small and large projects makes it easy to retain the information. You cab follow along with him and code as you go, or you can watch the lesson and download the sandbox file to use as a point of reference in the projects. He even shows you a few keyboard shortcuts with VS Code that I found very useful and has made coding much more fluid.

I look forward to taking more of your courses. Thanks again, Brad!

results.content:
Brad is a fantastic instructor! All sections were extremely easy to follow, each element of a technology was nicely explained with multiple demonstrations, which when working with HTML and CSS is extremely beneficial for understanding. The projects were fun and I had a great sense of accomplishment finishing each website, gaining confidence as I learned more and more about styling and good code practice. 
The inclusion of Flexbox, CSS Grid and Sass really take this beginner course to another level, providing everything an individual starting out with web development needs to create responsive, beautifully laid out static pages.

Thanks for the content Brad, onto some JS next.

Ryan

results.content:
Pretty much just a code-a-thon, although it starts out fairly strong. Brad is excellent at explaining the fundamentals but has the bad habit of extensively using a lot of things early on that don't even get explained until you're like 55% through the course, like the direct child syntax in CSS for example and pseudoselectors as well. Most of the projects except for the portfolio site are boring and the second project for the EdgeLedger site is essentially broken once you add the Javascript. If you do buy the course, I suggest skipping that segment entirely that has to do with implementing the jquery script. Jonas' CSS course is also better with more fun projects.

I'll give the course three stars for providing me with a concrete foundation and for a good early game. Unfortunately, the projects save for the portfolio one aren't really engaging. Also, you won't really learn how to design a site on your own or how to hash out the process of nesting all the divs, since you just follow what he does. 

Funnily enough, Brad has some better projects for free on his Youtube channel.

results.content:
I'm a beginner and started learning front-end coding through Brad's videos on YouTube. I learned so much more than I thought I would just through his free content alone that I decided to get more serious and buy some of his courses. This course is a must have for any beginner.

Brad speaks in a very relaxed tone and moves at a steady pace. He dives deep into the applications of the lessons he teaches and gives you a lot of room for inspiration and where to go on your own. Plus, he very rarely ever speaks of things you can do without showing you how to do it. My only constructive comment would be that sometimes you might find yourself rewriting some code because of some minor errors Brad makes going through the lesson. However, he always walks you through fixing them. Very minor stuff!

I recommend this course to anybody wanting to get a solid grasp of HTML and CSS to start building front-end web projects.

results.content:
Pros:- 
01) 'Sir' Brad is a great Teacher.
02) Most of the time is spent on practising stuff than just learning some textual information.
03) It's great that you can learn other web development skills from the same teacher(on Udemy and YouTube) than to just keep looking for everything on different platforms.
04) Course content is very vast, covering HTML, CSS, SASS and a bit of Git as well.
05) Many interesting projects to work during the course.
Cons:- 
01) Some parts of the course should be explained more thoroughly, it gets confusing sometimes(especially the hamburger menu and knowledge resume.)
Tips:-
01) Don't just rely on this course, do more coding every day to be confident in the skills you gained here.

results.content:
Great course for beginners looking to learn the fundamentals of web development (or none).

I had already learnt to write HTML and CSS (and a bit of JavaScript) to a decent standard, and used this course to strengthen the foundation I'd already built. I definitely learnt some things I didn't know before, and filled in most of the gaps in what I'd already learnt.

My only (very minor!) gripe is that some of the more complex CSS 'tricks' that Brad uses at a couple of points in this course were a bit confusing, but he does clarify that these examples use quite advanced CSS.

I highly recommend this course, especially if you're just starting out. 9/10.

results.content:
Gut strukturiert und gut aufeinander aufbauende Themen,  gute Beispiele sowohl in den Basics zum jeweiligen Thema als auch dann die praxisnahen Anwendungsbeispiele. Für totale Anfänger ist der Kurs jedoch nicht geeignet, die Grundlagen werden zu schlell durchgenudel, zu wenig Erklärungen und am Anfang ein paar einfache Übungen wären gut.

Der Dozent ist gut verständlich, auch wenn man nur mittelmäßig englisch kann, kommt man gut mit.

Ich bin bei den komplexeren Beispielen nicht ganz glücklich mit dem CSS-Selektoren-Wahnsinn ... mit teilweise unnötiger und nicht einheitlich gehandhabter Selektorenspezifität, andererseits muß man mit solchem Code auch klarkommen,  man sollte sich aber als Aufbaukurs etwas suchen, wo CSS mit BEM-System erklärt wird, eine Methode CSS übersichtlicher zu schreiben und zu organisieren. Aber das ist ein weiterführendes Thema. 

Bei den komplexeren Beispielen am Ende des Kurses wird zuwenig erklärt weshalb und warum diese und jene Klassen verwendet werden, welche Aufgaben sie haben, da wird gern auf die Basic-Lektionen verwiesen, was einem aber dann auch nicht hilft nachzuvollziehen, wieso das nun im aktuellen Beispiel so und so gemacht wird ohne Erklärung zum aktuellen Beispiel.

Alles in allem trotzdem ein guter Kurs, der die Html- und CSS- Basics und auch viele der fortgeschrittenen und modernen Techniken auch bezügl. CSS Flexbox + Grid,  Responsive Design und SASS behandelt.

english:
Well structured and topics that build well on each other, good examples both in the basics on the respective topic and then the practical application examples. However, the course is not suitable for total beginners, the basics are too quickly exhausted, too few explanations and at the beginning a few simple exercises would be good.

The lecturer is easy to understand, even if you only speak mediocre English, you can get along well.

I'm not quite happy with the CSS selector madness in the more complex examples ... On the other hand you have to deal with such code, but you should look for something as an advanced course, where CSS with BEM system is explained how to write and organize a method CSS more clearly. But this is a further topic. 

In the more complex examples at the end of the course there is not enough explanation why and why these and those classes are used, which tasks they have, there is often referred to the basic lessons, but this does not help to understand why this is done in the current example without explanation for the current example.

Nevertheless and all in all still a good course which covers the basics of Html and CSS and also many of the advanced and modern techniques concerning CSS Flexbox + Grid, Responsive Design and SASS.

results.content:
This is the first course that I have ever completed on Udemy, and I have purchased several over the last year or so, which speaks to the value that I felt I obtained from this course. I've broken my rating down into three categories:
1. Content - Two Stars
2. Presentation - Two Stars
3. Go Further - 1 Star

Content: There is a lot here for what you pay. He takes you through HTML, basic CSS, and introduces advanced concepts like sass which can help you drive your websites from something like you would have seen in the early 2000s to some very cutting edge, sleek websites of today. That being said, I do wish that there were more slides for each of the new concepts that he introduced, such as when to properly use them, what are the properties of each, etc. 1.5 stars

Presentation: His lectures are clear and easy to follow. He shows you the code, as well as how it will display in a browser. He speaks fluent English and there is no microphone distortion or other issues. However, again, I do feel that this is very much a "on rails" course. There isn't a lot of room for deviation away from what he is working on, as he can quickly dive into these very complex CSS stylings that I am still unclear on how they operate. 1.5 stars

3. Go Further: It's here that I think there was a missed opportunity. What I would have loved to have seen was discussions on how he came up with the website design, rather than just building it. Gave code review challenges to make sure we understood what we learned at the end of each section, as well as opportunities to push the site to another level by tacking on additional challenges at the end of a section.

He never really went into debugging or trying to understand why your version might not look like his, and what steps you might want to take to try and fix broken code, and I think that is a critical need for anyone interested in programming, because if you hit a wall, and don't understand how to fix it, you can easily give up on the course. .5 stars

In the end, I think this is a solid course with a lot of value if you push through it. I do think there is a large amount of room for improvement from an instructor perspective to really ensure that the lessons are sticking however. This is definitely one for students who are highly motivated and okay getting thrown in sometimes into very deep water.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I first off want to say that I have a ton of respect for Brad. He’s an absolutely amazing guy and is very knowledgeable of what he teaches. 

I already had a very strong background in HTML/ CSS before taking this course, but still feel like I learned things that I never really understood. 

With that said, I don’t think it’s a great choice for COMPLETE beginners. At times Brad doesn’t completely explain things and it’s more of just copying down. Luckily, with my experience, I don’t have trouble understanding what’s going on. 

You did a great job, Brad! Just for the future definitely focus on explaining more as you go.

results.content:
Great course! I've cherry picked what I wanted to watch and it has everything that I was unsure about. Brad also has a great workflow which shows his experience and provides the viewer with a solid approach to building websites. He also uses best practices within his code (good habits to copy). 

I also liked how Brad shows the older layout techniques, such as floats, and then shows how to update the same site using newer layout techniques (flexbox and grid). This allows you to work with older websites and demonstrates the method of applying the new features to them (important if you are updating a website for a client in the future). 

I would recommend this to anyone starting out in web development, as well as to experienced web developers who want to improve the way they approach their work.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Great course and I learn a lot. I would have some suggestions though. I feel some things are passed over in silence. Some of the style values are delivered like they were chosen by eye, from the top of the lecturer's mind. In fact they are very precise and need to stay this way for the layout to work. It's a volubility as changing one size will require a lot of other values to be adapted, which becomes tricky with bigger project. Secondly, sometimes I feel some properties newer for the student (flexbox, etc.) get less attention and description than the obvious and less important ones (like margin, padding or color).
Still, a great course though :)

Brad was awesome, no complaints.

The answers seem obvious to me now but perplexed me a bit throughout a large portion of the course.

results.content:
I would like to preface this review with the following - I have previous HTML&CSS coding experience!

I haven't written any HTML or CSS code in 3 years, so I went into this course with the goal of refreshing my knowledge.

The course covers all the basics in an understandable manner. It did what I wanted it do to for me, so I would say it does a decent job at that, BUT here is how Brad can make me recommend it:

1. Don't include JS anywhere, but final project - I felt like it distracted from the flow.

2. Include project designs as PSDs or JPGs - in a real job environment, you get a design and your responsibility is to turn into code. You do that by using PSDs mostly or in the worst case scenario JPGs. Why ? Because you use those for reference - pick colors, measure dimensions and distances, take font sizes and family etc. 
It would be really useful if the projects were setup as exercises, simulating real world coding scenario, rather then just watching the creator code, so we can actually practice and think about the things we've learned: Teach several concepts -> Exercise -> Solution.

3. More exercises! - there should be several exercises after every or most topics. Practice through coding and actually thinking about what you are doing, is the only way to internalize the knowledge gathered! This is so important!

4. No "Mobile first" at all ? - that was a big disappointment for me, because I remember that concept being a real big deal and it is. All of the projects or at least the final project, should've been done by implementing the "Mobile first". It is absolutely essential to learn to think that way from the start of your web journey in the modern mobile world! And the oddest thing is, I believe the concept was mentioned early on in the course and never expanded upon.

Hope this helps! 

Cheers!

The course covers all the basics in an understandable manner. It did what I wanted it do to for me, so I would say it does a decent job at that, BUT here is how Brad can make me recommend it:

1. Don't include JS anywhere, but final project - I felt like it distracted from the flow.

2. Include project designs as PSDs or JPGs - in a real job environment, you get a design and your responsibility is to turn into code. You do that by using PSDs mostly or in the worst case scenario JPGs. Why ? Because you use those for reference - pick colors, measure dimensions and distances, take font sizes and family etc.
It would be really useful if the projects were setup as exercises, simulating real world coding scenario, rather then just watching the creator code, so we can actually practice and think about the things we've learned: Teach several concepts -> Exercise -> Solution.

3. More exercises! - there should be several exercises after every or most topics. Practice through coding and actually thinking about what you are doing, is the only way to internalize the knowledge gathered! This is so important!

4. No "Mobile first" at all ? - that was a big disappointment for me, because I remember that concept being a real big deal and it is. All of the projects or at least the final project, should've been done by implementing the "Mobile first". results.content: I love Brad's courses.  I am a High School Teacher (12 years) with a Master's in Instructional Design.  I work with students that have disabilities and my son is blessed with a form of Autism.  I wanted to learn how to create applications that would benefit my students and son.  I have been on Udemy for over 3 years and Brads courses are exactly what I am looking for.  The courses are practical with enough info to get you going, but not too much to overwhelm you.  The hands-on projects are awesome.  I hate completing courses that dont have meaningful projects.  With a little work on your own, one could customize these projects to be placed in an online portfolio.  Sometimes I watch courses just to see different teaching styles.  Brad if you ever read this, I want to thank you for your efforts in assisting those that want to learn web development.  And as a fellow father of a child blessed with Autism, I hope that see the true joy of working with these individuals.  I wish you and your family the best and hope that you continue to keep up the good work.

results.content: Brad's teaching style is very down to earth and direct. He doesn't talk over your head or down to you. You don't feel like you're coming into it with a thousand points against you from the get go. It may help that he's North Shore folk. I've been watching his videos on Youtube for some time now and decided it was time to bite the bullet. I'm half way through the first of three purchased courses, and I'm already retaining what I've learned sooo much better than more expensive and heavily advertised video series I've slept through in the past. I'm excited to come home from a long day of work and to get studying. Highly recommended.

results.content:
This course is absolutely amazing! For just the €10 I paid for this using Brad's code on his website, this is so much value for the little money you pay. When I started with this course around almost 2 months ago, I had a little understanding about HTML and CSS. After taking this course I am able to build good looking websites with HTML, CSS and even SASS is included in this course, which is something you definitely want to check out. 

What makes this course even better is that the instructor, Brad Traversy, also has a good youtube channel where he posts high quality coding stuff which is also a great resource to learn from

Overall I think if you are looking for a high quality course about HTML and CSS, this is a very good choice. After taking this course you should be able to create some good looking website. 

Last, I want to say thank you to Brad for making a super high quality course available for everyone!

results.content:
This is a fantastic course. I did another highly rated course halfway on CSS and HTML but I was feeling lost because that directly jumped into making websites. Then I got this course, and thankfully, Brad goes over all the important HTML tags / topics one by one and then the CSS tags / topics so that I got a firm grasp on the basics. 

Only after that do we make a website project and by this time since I already got a good grasp of the basics, doing the project was a breeze. And after introducing new topics such as flexbox, animations etc also we get to do more projects and apply the concepts. 

I absolutely loved it. It has the right pace. The explanations are really good. The projects gives us a deeper understanding of the bigger picture of how everything fits together. I highly recommend it.

Very good course. Extremely detaild about the CSS part and with tons of practical examples to get a better understanding of what is teached.
Also support for questions is very good and precise.
I would suggest to restructure the projects video so they can become straight exercises (like giving a few tips, letting us build the pages and then confronting the solution with what the teacher did).
Sometimes some choices about core properties (those that aren't direct focus of the current lesson) used in the CSS classes are not explicitly explained, so doubts arise about why they were needed.

results.content:
I was pretty disappointed with this course. It felt like some of the fundamentals were glossed over, for example flexbox wrapping was only mentioned briefly, whereas it would've been useful to see more about how that works (and align-content) and cases when it might be useful.

The example projects looked nice, but for me didn't do enough to solidify the learning of the fundamentals to make it worth typing out all the code. For example the arrows on the timeline – this was non-obvious use of CSS and so a great opportunity to go into a bit more detail about how CSS borders are rendered and *why* those property values created an arrow shape. Instead it felt a bit like a magic trick.

I definitely come out of this course knowing more about CSS than I went into it, but I think I'd need to do more reading/studying if I wanted to build my own project unless it was very similar to the example projects.

results.content:
Well, it's hard to give such a poor feedback to someone I really enjoyed watching youtube vids. Brad was one of my fav person to watch by far!

Here on Udemy however, I'm finding quite confusing some of the vids. Not sure if I'm the only one having a hard time, I see so many people enjoying the course according to their rating but I'm not, I was expecting to get a better understanding about the concepts.

Sometimes things get weird too, in one of the last vids that I watched I raised a question about the "overflow" attribute since it was not explained in the earlier classes and all of the sudden it was used in the current video. And the response I got was an external link explaining about it.

Well before raising the question I surely googled and found many sources, but my point is, I got confused with this attribute introduced all of the blue. 

I guess it's okay since it's exepcted from a dev to search external docs, but I was hoping to get some help understanding it.

IDK in general Brad's vid are really good but I'm surely having some hard time in some of the vids. I think I need a break, maybe the next time I try this course I might have a better experience and possibly change my rating.

I hate to just watch a vid and call it a day, I really enjoy watching and practice it right after by replicating the code / project by myself. Otherwise I won't really learn but this time I'm not able to.

results.content:
I think this course perfectly fits for people who are total newcomers to the world of web development and want to start to learn it from the very basics. Towards the end of the course Brad also introduces advanced CSS concepts and projects so I guess more advanced people can find some interesting parts as well. I belong to the previous group and I consider myself as an enthusiastic self-learner of web development.

Before I started Brad’s course here on Udemy I’d enrolled for a programmer’s school in my country which would have provided me an accredited certificate by the end of course. It was quite similar in terms of the format, we had online classes every Saturday for 8 hours which were just as “interactive” (not at all) as a course here on Udemy, a lot less project oriented (compared to Brad’s course) and cost a lot more money. So after the HTML&CSS part I decided to quit the school and turn to Udemy and by the recommendation of one my friends I found Brad’s course. I have to say I learnt a lot more from Brad than from the school in these 21 hours for which I am very grateful for him and for Udemy as well.

What are the things that I really enjoyed?
-	first of all, I believe that on a video course, finding the educator whose speaking style suits you is crucial, and I was very comfortable with Brad’s voice the whole time
-	the time given to each and every concept was just right, not too long, not too short
-	the course includes projects which you can build a lot easier and faster (probably) with JS or React however it is realllly cool to see that you can do basically the same with pure HTML and CSS
-	learning the clear structure of the HTML and the CSS file that Brad teaches us. In my opinion this is one of the biggest learnings you can acquire from the whole course. Brad teaches you a very well organized system of HTML and CSS code which you can follow later on in your coding career.

What are the things that I missed?
-	quizzes, which I know are a lot more “lexical” type of knowledge testing however I believe that short quizzes can ensure that students understood the concepts
-	“homework” + solutions. I think the projects could have been organized in a way that Brad shows the end result, what the website should look like by the end, gives some help (like colors used, pictures and so on and so forth) and let us write it alone and shows his final code in the end, explaining why he wrote it in a certain way. Now this one I know is a learning way that depends on us learners because if we wanted to we could do it this way by ourselves but still, I believe that incorporating this type of knowledge organization and transfer in a video course ensures the deepening of learning in a more efficient way.

Why should you choose this course?
-	because you can learn how to structure your HTML and CSS in a clean and well organized way
-	because you can learn the basics of writing a website before you jump into higher abstractions like React and this gives you a deeper and better understanding of coding
-	because Brad is not a “dead” educator, he’s still very active and productive and has thousands of videos on YouTube related to web development and he approaches the topics from many-many perspectives

I hope this review helps some of you making a decision about where to start your web developer path.

results.content:
best teacher ever, I learned from him, bootstrap, react, html, css.
 
I remember when i took his first course( he  was doing it for a third party so his name was not available) and his memory stayed with me for a very long time.

I lost him for a number of years and I then, serendipity, I did manage to find him again publishing under his own company.

Why he is unique? he breaks complicated areas of expertise into small chunks, he explains the why and then with his hand-on approach shows you the way. Finally  he repeats it until it clicks.

He loves learning, he has been doing it for years  and this makes him a domain expert.

There is something more also all great teachers have. He wants to give the ability to people to develop their potential  and his gift is unconditional. It does come across.

Finally, he shows up  as a human being, there is nothing surface only in Mr Traversy, his teaching, even technical, is full of the underlying  emotions all developers struggle with.

results.content:
This is a great course. I'm not an absolute beginner and what I want is to sort of re-do some HTML/CSS starting from the basics, and to catch up with what HTML5 and CSS3 offer.

The course does a good job explaining both of the above, as well as the distinction between the two, so now it's much more clear why I should appreciate and use modern options such as Flex and Grid.

My only objection is that in some cases theory is needed but not provided (not enough anyway), making it so that I can only memorize to use something without understanding why it's used.
Fortunately this isn't the case for majority of the content.

Overall, It's amazing and I learned a lot and I'm only half-way so far. I'm eager to finish it and apply what I've learned.

I would recommend anyone interested in Web development to take this course first.

results.content: I wore out my pause button.  The instructor goes way too fast even for someone, like me, who has previous coding experience and already know a good bit about the topic. The instructor definitely is an expert at his craft, but is not adept at providing clear explanations and instruction.  The class is like watching a gamer play a game, telling the audience what he's doing.  My recommendation is to buy a book and work through it at your pace.  Think of this course as a window into someone else's workflow and hopefully you can pick up a few tips here and there (if you're fast enough with the pause button).

results.content:
The course offered a great deal more than I expected. It is a very good introductory course on HTML5 and CSS3. Brad introduced complexity with each project; every new aspect of HTML5 and CSS3 had a purpose and could be reused in my own projects because they are things that genuinely enhance a site.

There were times when I felt explanations for why styling was done a certain way, would have increased understanding, but overall, explanations of each aspect of the technology being dealt with was very good.

I found this course to be one of the best introductions to website design and development that was not overwhelming and did not seek to be all things to all men.

Definitely worth the money!

results.content:
Superb course. 
This course is by far the best CSS and HTML course out on Udemy. The course is short and delivers what it promises. This course has a good balance of theory and practice. Instead of trying to explain all the theories behind CSS, Brad takes a project-based approach to learning. This aided in my understanding of CSS properties and, more importantly, how and when to use flexbox and grid. 
Additionally, the final project of this course involved using Sass to build complex portfolio websites. After this course, I feel comfortable to use Sass in my future projects.

results.content:
If you're completely new to Web Design and are looking to dive in to get started, then this is a good course to take.

Personally, I prefer a bit more theory and technical information to really understand the nuts and bolt of 'why' things are functioning the way they do, but that isn't really the focus of this course.

However, with that said - as I mentioned this course is perfect for anyone looking to to get well acquainted with the fundamentals of HTML and CSS. There's more than enough content here get you started. Once you make it to the end of Brad's course, you will be more than well-equipped to start branching out into more complex and sophisticated layouts and designs.

Again, if you're new to HTML & CSS, you will learn A LOT of the fundamentals necessary to get you to the next level - which is part of the process of web design & development; continual learning.

results.content:
I was debating whether to go for this course or to pick a course that is focused on Advanced CSS, but so far I must say I'm glad I picked this one. 
I will keep updating this review as I progress through the course.
Update at 10% - I am blown away at the amount of content that is being taught in such a little time. Although Brad insists that you skip the HTML basics if you are already familiar, which I thought I was, I am so glad I didn't. I liked that pretty much every bit of detail is covered in it, such as meta tags, which I didn't know about, as well as its importance with SEO. There are also plenty of useful tips on how to use VSCode, which no other course I have followed covered.
Update at 50%: Covers a lot of the essential topics. Projects are good, but explanations could be slightly improved. Good transition from concept to concept.

results.content:
I took this course after completing another Udemy course on full-stack web development. I did so because I wanted a more in-depth understanding of HTML and, more importantly, CSS, and not have to rely solely on frameworks. I feel that this course has provided me with what I was looking for, and it has certainly motivated me to start working on some original projects of my own.

Mr Traversy's explanations are generally clear and insightful. The course has a rapid build-up, that I experienced as fast enough to be challenging, yet slow enough to keep things comprehensive. 

This course does not employ a hold-your-hand style of teaching. Technical concepts are explained well, but I would advise students to definitely code along from scratch with the videos rather than simply watch them passively. Also make sure to regularly pause the video to research certain concepts in greater depth, and whatever you do, takes notes! 
Especially during later projects, you may want to take some time to do the math on why Mr Traversy chooses certain heights, widths, and similar values; as the course mainly focuses on the workings of the code itself, explanations of such details are sparse, but trying to backwards-engineer the reasoning behind certain design choices can really deepen your understanding of the course material. 

An aspect that especially liked about the course is Mr Traversy's honesty. When he makes a mistake during a project, he does not edit it out, but instead highlights it and makes a point of showing how he solves it. This gives a realistic view of web development, as even professionals make mistakes, and retracing your steps to solve the resulting problems is vital.

As to cons, I would like to point out that some of the  services referenced in the lectures require payment (such as certain hosting platforms). This was an unpleasant surprise that kept me from actually doing some of the exercises. However, I did not feel that this damaged my learning experience. 

Also note that later sections in the course may be a bit too fast-paced for absolute beginners. When you reach the sections on web hosting and Sass, prepare to do additional research on how to use the command line, NodeJS, Git, and similar concepts, especially if this is your first web development course. Some of the commands Mr Traversy uses did not work as expected on my machine, and required small modifications that I had to search for online. Nevertheless, I think that this is another normal part of (learning) web development, so I do not think it should discourage students from taking this course.  

Finally, I have slightly mixed feelings about the Q&A section. It seems the section is being monitored, because most questions are answered fairly quickly. However, answers are often very brief, sometimes to the point of not actually solving the problem. Then again, I could find answers to most of my questions by re-watching Mr Traversy's excellent explanations, doing some additional research, or thanks to help from other students. 

All in all, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone seeking to gain a solid understanding of CSS!

results.content:
Brad is a great teacher. He takes his time to introduce and explain HTML elements and CSS selectors, walks you through a project where these elements/selectors are used so that you see how they all come together. 

I've taken a similar course where the instructor just starts writing markup without the why, although the course states "No coding or design experience necessary". This course is much better.

My scholarship runs out on 30th December 2020 and although I will be unable to finish before it ends, I will recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn HTML/CSS.

If you think he moves too fast, choose a speed of 0.75, you'll be fine :)

results.content:
As always, Brad is insanely good! I will agree that some things he mentions , and the way that he mentions them, are some kind of advanced, but with a little bit of research, you will get to the point! Awesome course, awesome instructor! 

Something I want to mention, you will never ever ever be a good programmer if you just watch videos and lectures. You really need to practice like pretty much everyday. When he builds sites, with Float or Flex-box or even Grid, after the site that you build with him, make 2 or more sites with the same style. Move to the next, etc. He is explaining what float is or what flex-direction is or even what font-size is, but really you need to combine everything, and practice! Practice a lot!
Well played, Brad! One more course that is huge.
results.content_html:
As always, Brad is insanely good! I will agree that some things he mentions , and the way that he mentions them, are some kind of advanced, but with a little bit of research, you will get to the point! Awesome course, awesome instructor!

Something I want to mention, you will never ever ever be a good programmer if you just watch videos and lectures. You really need to practice like pretty much everyday. When he builds sites, with Float or Flex-box or even Grid, after the site that you build with him, make 2 or more sites with the same style. Move to the next, etc. He is explaining what float is or what flex-direction is or even what font-size is, but really you need to combine everything, and practice! Practice a lot!
Well played, Brad! One more course that is huge.

results.content:
To be perfectly clear: the information itself is well-presented by a knowledgable instructor. But as some point it turns into watching someone competent doing something, and that is not the same as learning.

The problem is there are several projects added on to the course which seem poorly planned out. Whereas the first sections explaining fundamentals are great (it's worth it for these alone!), it then turns into ad-hoc explanations after coding things in real time - "Did we do this?" "I think we did that" in a stream of consciousness fashion.

In short, it is obvious why the fundamentals are explained (this is what we all need to know), but it is not made plain why the projects are explained since copying projects is not inherently useful in the way fundamentals always are.

results.content:
This course certainly deserves 5 stars! Brad is an excellent instructor and the amount of experience you'll gain just from following along with him will have you feeling confident in your HTML and CSS abilities. This is definitely the best 10 bucks I've spent in a while. 

My only suggestion would be to include some resources for studying outside of the sandboxes like flashcards or worksheets of some kind. Everything is very clearly explained in the videos, but it would be helpful to have some resources containing important information in an organized format so that I could focus on following along. There are a few concepts I've been having trouble with that I remember being explained (clearly and effectively), but it's difficult to locate the exact moment where it's covered in the videos.

Thanks, Brad! I'm excited to take your Javascript course next!

results.content:
Brad is brilliant. I already knew HTML & CSS prior to taking this course. I started on his JavaScript course and thought to myself, I've always wanted to better understand how to properly use HTML5 tags and also how to hopefully make my markup more semantic. I feel like I got all of these things from this course PLUS more. I ended up taking pretty much the whole thing. Brad exposed me to things I had been putting off like CSS Grid and SASS. He also explain flex properties in a way that actually helps me better understand how to use them rather than guessing how to use them. results.content:
This has been a fantastic course. I already knew some HTML and CSS and have made sites/apps with Django but already have seen drastic changes with my own little practice projects during the course. Brad is a fantastic instructor, the lessons sound very unscripted and the way he explains things is very natural (some course instructors sound a bit robotic or like it's a lecture script being read), which feels like I'm being "instructed" rather than just watching someone code. The course doesn't lack in any area, I felt HTML and CSS, as well as great design techniques and tricks are covered - I use VScode and I've discovered a lot of keyboard shortcuts and extensions through the course which I didn't know about before. I also feel confident with SASS now, something I've only heard of before the course. 
Now that I have finished the course, I will focus on practising what I've learned with more little projects, but very soon I shall be taking Brad's Javascript course which I very much look forward to. 

Thanks Brad!

results.content:
Overall good class, particularly through the first 13 sections of the course. There are occasionally some points where the instructor rushes through a topic or a task in one of the projects where students will probably find themselves referencing other sources to see what exactly is being done. All projects in this course are guided and use repetition to reinforce what is being learned. While this is certainly productive, I would also have liked to see a few more challenges or assignments where the instructor gives you an idea of what you need to accomplish, maybe a few hints or ideas as how to proceed, and then provide his solution for students to compare their attempts to. 

I do believe the course gets extremely rushed starting with the intro to SASS section, including getting SASS installed and running. Also worth mentioning is that the sections on SASS will need updating since some of the commands being used (@import for example) are slated for removal by 2022 in favor of the more modular approach that has been implemented more recently. In addition to continuing one's learning of web development with Javascript, PHP, etc. I'd also recommend students find other resources/classes that go in to SASS in more detail.

results.content: The course exceeded my expectations! This was much better than looking through W3schools myself. I appreciated Brad's comment of how he uses certain things, in other words his coding practices. The projects were amazing, and they were often long so it's important to pause sometimes to consider what the code he writes accomplishes. My suggestion is to write a ton of comments along the way. The course was very in-depth and complete. results.content:
First thing, I just wanted to mention that I just finished the whole course 100%, so my thoughts are based on the whole thing (not only on some of the initial lessons).

I am honestly pretty disappointed, I stared with a medium knowledge on the topic and expected to get learn some more advanced things, but no, even if in the intro the course is said to be for everyone, I would say it is pretty much aimed at beginners.

So if you are already knowledgeable in HTML/CSS I thing this is not for you, if you're just starting I guess this is not too bad.

The explanations are ok but the instructor often does stuff without explaining why and the specifics, also I never asked a question since I got the feeling that he doesn't actually checks those.

Iterating on what I said above, I was pretty surprised that not once in the course he mentioned css' specificity, once he even had a selector not working, increased the specificity and not explained properly why it wasn't working before.
I may be wrong but I think any respectable course covering css should at least talk about specificity (this is the tip of the aisberg, there are so many instances of stuff like this throughout the course ).

All in all I can say that I sort of enjoyed the course, I learned a couple of things and coded along the projects, which were nice (even though they need much more fine-tuning).
I don't thing the course is terrible or anything, but it definitely won't gave you an very advanced knowledge on the topic, if you are already somewhat good on HTML/CSS you may be better off looking for some other course, but if you're just getting started I would imagine this could be quite good for you.

results.content:
The overall content is great and helpful. 
However, as a beginner, I failed to follow the lecturer in the project videos. He codes too fast and without enough instructions for me, a beginner. I have to stop the video, check what he wrote, copy that, then resume the video. Even if I play at 75% speed I still need to pause the video from time to time to follow each step.
Additionally, some nuances were also not notified in the project videos, such as the difference between ".flex-columns.flex-reverse" and ".flex-columns .flex-reverse" (with and without a space between two classes) in CSS. I noticed that when I could not reproduce the style in the video and Googled that. 
I learned a lot from these projects, but I think I could get more out of them if the lecturer could slow down a little bit and explain more details in the project videos.

results.content:
Pluses and negatives. Pluses first: Comprehensive and informative. Gave me all the tools I needed whilst not holding the viewer's hand and encouraging them to create projects themselves. Past a certain point practice makes perfect and Brad makes a good point of stressing this throughout the course. It contains everything needed to obtain a decent level of proficiency in both HTML & CSS. This is a good course for revision & to hone your skills in htML & CSS, but it is not ideal for a fresh beginner as I will explain in the negatives.

Negatives: Not for beginners. It's just not. Although the instructor starts at a relaxed pace they will eventually reach a point where they will raunch right on ahead of anyone is a beginning developer & additional resources will be needed to keep pace. That's not to say the information isn't included in the course, it's just included somewhere. Teaching & programming are very different skills that don't always found together. As somebody who has done both, I can certainly attest to this. The roadmap beyond a  point is poor and the teaching style is likely not ideal for somebody brand new to programming so beginners will be warned. You may fly in the beginning but past a point you may struggle if you have no prior experience with CSS.

results.content:
Excellent course! I really liked the sandbox style approach to the basics. Learning this stuff it is a lot to remember, so it's nice to have a reference to come back to when  you need it. Overall I think Brad is a great teacher. He has a pleasant voice and is easy to listen to. 

I feel some of the more advanced css topics could have done with a little more in-depth explanation, he sometimes tended to go a little fast in those sub-sections. All in all though, I think Brad has done a great job with this course and I hope to move on to JS after this. 

Thanks for this course!

results.content:
I loved the course and highly recommend it for anyone who is completely new to HTML/CSS. Brad drops little nuggets of information you will not hear in almost any other tutorial while he codes. You can tell he has a vast amount of experience working with HTML and CSS from his years as a programmer. 

My one nitpick is I felt in the end I was only copying the code Brad was typing instead of really engaging with my learning. He played with assignments earlier in the course, but abandoned it quickly. I really liked the assignment-answer structure and wish he would have used it more. I learn best by trying and goofing up, not having everything handed to me on a platter. But that's me. 

Thanks Brad! I look forward to another course together.

results.content: Very practical, the best class in html/css available at Udemy. Would highly recommend to anyone with basic understanding of html/css. If you want to see the style of lectures, check out Traversy Media youtube channel for about 1 h long tutorials on html/css. Although the Udemy class uses studio vis code (sublime on youtube) and is just better than youtube videos. Brad goes much deeper into html/css than other similar classes available at Udemy. As others mentioned, you might want to skip the first project with floats and move to flexbox/grid.

results.content:
A really good crash course on HTML5 and CSS3. I highly recommend this course for anybody looking to supplement their front end framework knowledge with modern web design.

I've been focusing a lot of my attention on JavaScript and JavaScript frameworks on Udemy. I feel I have a pretty good grasp on those but was having a hard time creating anything worthwhile with them due to my lack of knowledge regarding styling. 

This course takes you through building a couple modern looking websites as well as a few impressive looking mini-projects. I was genuinely surprised at how much I picked up in such a short time and by the end I was even pausing the video to implement my own designs. Having these projects and videos to reference later will be invaluable as I move on to building bigger and better things with my current skill-set.

results.content:
As the course progresses, the process gets very rushed. For example, in the flex course Brad gives us examples of different content alignments. I’m going along, trying each out and getting a feel for them. Then he says “I’m just gonna paste these options in here and comment them out.” He has them on his clipboard, so this happens for him in under a second. Over here, I’m trying to pause the video so that I can copy them into my cheat sheet. 

My request: please pause between moves. Even consider doing them more than once, so that we can follow along as we would in a classroom and get a feel for the practice without having to rewind the video.

results.content: This course was really very beneficial for me, as a person just learning how to do HTML and CSS. In the beginning of the course he was very thorough in how he taught, not only teaching us how to write Html and Css but also tips and trick that are hugely beneficial to speeding up the process.  He taught organization, different layouts and so many cool projects. My only knock may be that near near the 3/4 mark he started to get too fast, and I had to stop the video and go back  so many times, also I felt like he expected us to know everything that he had previously taught so he did things very fast.  The project also became less learning and more follow what I do, you should know this by now.  Also some of his resource files were confusing because they were finished products, not follow along. All being said I would give this course a 9.8 out of 10. I really learned so much and I look forward to taking more of his courses on Udemy and Youtube. Thank you!

results.content:
I have watched your 1:25 hours long CSS tutorial on Youtube and I am glad I have spotted the link below that video pointing to this course. I truly enjoyed that video and learned a lot. Now, this Udemy course will teach me HTML and further reinforce what I have learned about CSS in your Youtube tutorial. I have earned my private pilot licence last year but due to the COVID-19 crisis, I have lost my job and cannot afford to continue flight school. I was a flight attendant and earned a decent wage. Now I am a hotel receptionist and it really sucks. At the same time, I have to understand that aviation suffers too due to the crisis. It is a great opportunity then to learn something new, something valuable and I am glad that I found you to be my guide in this - for me - uncharted territory. My goal is to learn something I can later build on, and eventually, make profitable. I find front and back-end web development truly exciting, and this Udemy course is my very first step in this direction.

Halfway-through-course Update:
Brad, you are an incredible teacher. From absolutely zero, I am now able to design simple yet beautiful static websites, and I am only halfway through the course. As soon as I finish this, I will immediately get started with your Javascript course. Enrolling on any course made by you is money well spent! Thank you so much!

results.content:
Only up to lesson 12 or so and really appreciating the VS Code editor the instructor chose.  With all the shortcut tips he provides, it makes me feel like I could do this all day long and really get a huge amount of coding done!  The instruction pace is nice and steady and easy to understand, with a logical flow of information.  

It has been years since I taught myself HTML and CSS, and this is a perfect review and update on the new HTML5 rules I missed.  I can't wait to get to the website creation steps.

PS...If you need hype and rah-rah to stay motivated to learn, look elsewhere.  The instructor has a "just the facts ma'am" presentation style.  All-in-all, the number and quality of extra tips he gives makes the course of far greater value than other courses covering these topics.

results.content:
Just finished the course and it is just outstanding. 

Here are the only cons for me: first, it does not have enough "challenges". It will be up to you to create your challenge or just follow along with Brad's tutorial. I am a firm believer that in coding, you learn more by doing than listening/watching so I just hoped there were more of that. The second one is that there is no "mobile-first" web development tutorial in this course. Brad has one in his YT channel so I am wondering why he has not included something like that in this course which is really an important fundamental for web development in this generation.

Anyway, this course definitely has what you need to learn basic to advance HTML/CSS but it will be up to you to decide if you want to go deeper. Overall, a highly recommended course and probably one of the best (if not the best) out there. TAKE IT!

results.content:
This is an Excellent tutorial for beginners into web development, as the title says it covers all the HTML and CSS basics and well beyond. The highlights of the course are without a doubt Flexbox, CSS Grid and all the code-along projects and challenges that Brad carefully prepared for us. 

Essentially you will learn how to have your website on the internet from absolute scratch and 100% DIY style. 
Bonus points for introducing us to modern technologies like Sass and advise on hosting/cloud providers.

Last but not least Brad makes explanations very easy to understand and follow, gives examples and encourages you to go and make your own mistakes, ask questions, learn. This is exactly what you want from an instructor, it sure did help me at least.

results.content: This course is worth every penny and then some. I paid for a course at a local community college and didn't learn half of the stuff I have learned so far in this course. The instructor's explanations are good. The explanation of meta tags and why they are used is great. You can tell the instructor has taken a lot of time to put this course together with a lot of important and relevant information that the student can use in their future career as a developer. The only thing I think the instructor should do is to work on is finding ways to explain terms and concepts in a way someone who has never heard them before can understand. I can tell he is trying hard to do this, but there are some things that I still couldn't understand because of the developer lingo. Other than that, this course is excellent and deserves the five star rating I have given it.

results.content: I loved this course! It's a great choice for anyone who is new to HTML and CSS and is looking for somewhere to start. results.content:
Update!  Today's date is June 8, 2020 and I just finished the whole course!  Yey!

Looking back at the old comment below, I recalled that prior to taking this course, I have a very silly problem not being able to differentiate Div's from Spans, Inline and block elements, etc.  After a few months of working slowly on this HTML and CSS course, I can say that I am at least confident now with the way I code with both HTML and CSS.  I now understands the box model, how to properly use padding, margins, etc.  I also now understands positioning like relative and absolute positioning - things that always confuse me of when I initially got this course.  I must say that after learning so much from this course, I can't thank Brad Traversy enough for sharing his awesome skills in programming.

I am going to continue mastering CSS, but for now, I am going to start learning JavaScript and probably Bootstrap as well.  Phew!  That was a ride - a really worth it ride.

Old Comment: I've proven that I am indeed a visual learner.  I've read about this topic a lot of times but Inline and Block elements, the difference between DIV and Span just became clear after I watched this video.  I am so glad I bought this in Udemy.
results.content_html:
Update! Today's date is June 8, 2020 and I just finished the whole course! Yey!

Looking back at the old comment below, I recalled that prior to taking this course, I have a very silly problem not being able to differentiate Div's from Spans, Inline and block elements, etc. After a few months of working slowly on this HTML and CSS course, I can say that I am at least confident now with the way I code with both HTML and CSS. I now understands the box model, how to properly use padding, margins, etc. I also now understands positioning like relative and absolute positioning - things that always confuse me of when I initially got this course. I must say that after learning so much from this course, I can't thank Brad Traversy enough for sharing his awesome skills in programming.

I am going to continue mastering CSS, but for now, I am going to start learning JavaScript and probably Bootstrap as well. Phew! That was a ride - a really worth it ride.

results.content:
This course has definitely lived up to me expectations. I'm familiar with Brad's tutorials on YouTube and I'm a big fan of his style of teaching. This course is very much in the same style as his YouTube videos but much more organized. If you are not a fan of 'code-along' style tutorials, this may not be the course for you. Brad takes you through the concepts and syntax with the help of examples. Some of the explanations may be a little fast paced for newcomers but the points are driven home with each major project. I also appreciated the inclusion of SASS as well as guides on how to deploy your projects.

There are some parts of the course I found a bit difficult to understand, such as animations, however I feel like I'll get the hang of them in time as I do more projects. Other than that, this is a very good course for a comprehensive introduction to CSS.

results.content:
So far, this course is exactly what I need. I already have some experience with HTML. However, absolute beginners may find it confusing from time to time, it is a little too fast but it is possible to slow down the video. Some of the definitions that are used in those videos can also be overwhelming for _absolute_ beginners. Otherwise, I like it so far.

Update: 15.06.2020
Halfway through the course. Brad doesn't disappoint. Actually, I am already looking forward to enroll into more of his courses. The pace at times goes maybe a bit too fast, but Brad has an astonishing amount of knowledge and is breaking it down very nicely. But again, total beginners may find it overwhelming.

results.content:
I learned about Brad Traversy's courses trough his free youtube tutorial HTML/CSS from the beginning. I thought that was a very good tutorial and was from there directed here. I made a Udemy account and bought his HTML/CSS from the beginning course.  It was easy to understand at first for people with no coding experience.  At the end it goes fast, but everything he does was explained in courses before, so if you don't remember what it was he's doing exactly, you can look it up again in previous videos. I like that kind of approach.
When i was halfway the course i was blown away on the quality of the content, and the rate that i was learning new stuff. Thats when i decided to buy Brad's Javascript, PHP, Bootstrap & Materialize courses already.

In General, this course completely exceeded my expectations, and those were already pretty high.

Thanks Brad, for such a nice info packed quality course!

Cheers

*Moving on to the Javascript course*

results.content: This is course provided me a road map to learning basic website development after I spent a year figuring out the best way to start creating websites on my own. While I found the course to be beneficial, I started to experience problems towards the end as the instructor moved forward into implementing sass. Mainly, my own sass code was not executing correctly in the browser and I did not get much forewarning as to what might go wrong. I am new at this either way, so I expect some problems I ran into are due to my own inexperience. Regardless, I feel confident enough to begin creating webpages for friends before going on to learning new programming languages and implementing what I have learned with my career. Brad really knows his stuff!

results.content: I had taken a previous CSS course but was not content with the skills I had acquired.  I couldn't make proper use of Flex/Grid and I just didn't understand how to properly format my mark up and styling sheets. After this course I def feel 100x more comfortable. I still have some work to do and there are moments where I get stumped but that's with any skill someone is just learning. I will say the speed of the course was a little tough for me at first, I felt as if Brad was moving a little too fast but honestly I paid close attention and took notes through out his lectures which really helped me when I needed to reference something on a personal project. I tried my best to not have to look at the example sites we built and I'm actually surprised that a lot of the information stuck with me and makes a lot more sense now.  Great course and thank you!

results.content:
The course is good overall, and there is a lot to be gained from it. 

There are a couple of things that warrant this lower rating for me. 

1. I believe that the semantics of his html and css are frankly pretty bad. 
First of all, compound selectors are generally frowned upon in the industry, for multiple reasons from the fact that it slows down older browsers, to the fact that it makes it extremely difficult to read. This is why functional CSS and BEM architecture (which Brad doesn’t cover)  became the standard in the industry - in order to remove the need for tons of compounded selectors (such as div div ul li a).  Throughout the whole course, I don’t believe Brad uses clean CSS practices and unfortunately I personally think this is pretty bad because people who watch this course tend to be beginners, and if you build bad habits from the start, it’s very difficult to break out of them.. 

2. During the projects that Brad goes through making with you, he uses a lot of features without much explanation as to why. One example of this would be when he went through demonstrating SASS functions, he didn't take the time to explain what a function parameter is and how it works by passing in an argument etc. For people with programming experience (like myself), we can get by fine, but if you’re coming to this as a complete beginner, it’s likely you will struggle to understand. 

TL:DR
  So while there is a lot of great information you will gain from this course, such as what many of the CSS properties do, and some great visual designs, I simply can’t recommend it as a standalone course. Saying that, if you continue your studies afterwards in order to make sure you are programming in a clean and maintainable manner, then this course can be a good resource for certain things as well.

Alternatively, if a clean CSS section is added to this course in the future, then I think this would warrant a much higher rating!

I have to say, I mean no disrespect to Brad, this is just my honest and (personal) opinion on this course.

These are my thoughts, if anyone disagrees, please feel free to comment your opinion, I’m always happy for a healthy discussion.

results.content: This is my second long web development HTML/CSS course and, of the two, this is substantially better. Brad Traversy is awesome. He sets a great pace for learning, is well organized, and is simply an excellent teacher. My learning method is to listen to each section at 1.5-1.75x normal speed taking notes/bookmarks. Then I repeat at normal speed and code along. Brad's course works perfectly for this approach. The first course I took was with Colt Steele, which was highly rated, but I found it to be choppy, disorganized, and had many places in the course where they had to make corrections. This course by Brad is substantially better and I recommend the course and Brad highly.

Here and there I wish you would explain a bit more about why, but that would take more time. This is an outstanding course. I know that I can now design web sites with confidence, creating elegant code that hopefully includes smart and visually appealing web sites. That last part is not something you can necessarily teach. Again, thank you so much for the time you have put into creating this and teaching us so well.

results.content:
This is exactly what I was looking for, and so far, it has done a great job of explaining the basics of HTML and CSS. (halfway review)

It was an excellent course, clear and with very useful projects. The only part that could stand to improve a bit, in my opinion, is that it is useful to keep repeating what certain coding terms mean, again and again, so that they stick, including why it is better to use X instead of Y. It's great to see them being used practically, but we should also be reminded of what they actually mean.

results.content:
This course starts with the basics of HTML and CSS with explanations and examples that you can follow along with. The power of this course is the projects that are included. 

You get to see how to use HTML and CSS to create responsive sites. Brad covers CSS flex and CSS grid, and he takes the time to explain what he is doing and why he is doing it. 

You get all of the images and starter templates for each project, and the finished sites so you can refer to them if you get stuck. I have completed 2 other of Brad's courses, and this one was very good. Highly recommended.

results.content:
I really want to say thank you to Brad for creating such a great comprehensive course! The reason I took this course is I was taking another Web Developer Bootcamp course on Udemy and found there was a lot of gaps in my knowledge when it came to more advanced CSS and JS (I will be taking his JS course also). I wanted to take a break from the Bootcamp course and really get a firm grip on modern CSS practices. This course did all that and more for me. Not only did we learn a lot of modern CSS but we also did a bit of SASS at the end. I came away from this course with a good understanding of CSS and a few great projects under my belt. One thing I found important throughout the course is to go over what you learned and build similar looking projects from what I learned. It’s easy to watch and copy but another thing to do it yourself. 

I originally came across Brad’s courses via his Youtube channel. That is also an awesome resource for future developers, by the way. I love Brad’s chilled and real approach to coding. He takes away all the BS and gives you the real deal. Sure for many of the projects he had it pre-coded but there were times where something came up that he wasn’t expecting. Instead of cutting them out of the video and making it looked like he always knew what he was doing, he left it in. To me this inspired confidence because it showed me that Brad (and many other professional coders) aren’t some immortal god. They are human like you and me. The only difference being he has more years of experience. I believe if we were to stick with this long term, in 10, 20 or 30 years we could have this level of skill also. 

All in all I highly recommend this course. I honestly don’t think I have any negatives to say about it. Thanks Brad for your incredible work. On to Javascript now  ?.

results.content: This course goes in depth through many of the fundamentals of HTML and CSS and is a fantastic starting point for those wanting to delve into front end web development. I would recommend that you practice the concepts learned here outside the course in conjunction as you go through the course (through your own projects, etc) so that you really learn the concepts. You can always refer back to the projects and sandbox files as a reference for building. Overall, great course!

results.content: I am a the typical developer who makes things work well, but they will be can't make them pretty. No matter how hard I tried I always seem to have crappy looking pages that I would wind up jury rigging to fight against the design gods that were unhappy with me for reason. Brad did a great job of explaining how all the parts worked together and encouraged students to try some things differently then the way he did it. I was able to immediately solve some design problems I was having in my own projects and am becoming more confident in doing nicer looking UI in my systems now that I understand how things work. At this point I have dropped my former belief that design is some dark art that requires prayer. Very enjoyable course  I learned a lot, and think more developers should spend the time to at least be familiar with what is going on on top of their code.

results.content: If you are familiar with Brad's Youtube tutorials it will come as no surprise: he is an excellent teacher and this course really takes you from humble HTML beginnings all the way to advanced CSS concepts through a mix of theory and hands-on projects. Although I was familiar to a certain degree with most of the content of this course (although I really needed to brush up on everything from flexbox onwards.....) I feel that the pace is suitable to anyone including absolute beginners. Another really strong point of this course is the quality of the projects we are building that makes you eager to learn how to do them and allow you to understand the theory better while picking up plenty of additional, practical knowledge along the way. In two words, highly recommended!

results.content: Wow, really amazing course, Brad. I loved it all the way through and I wish it just wouldn't end. Brad explains all of the topics covered in the course in great depth and provides you with the knowledge and skills to be able to build very powerful projects. This course was my first time being exposed to HTML & CSS and pretty much web development as a whole. I have a good amount of programming experience before this though. This course goes well beyond basic CSS and HTML which I am very thankful for. Flexbox and CSS Grid were explained excellently and I can easily see myself being confused with those topics if it weren't for Brad's videos on them. The introduction to Sass and even a bit of npm and git were soooo helpful. I was very confused with npm and did not fully understand git and this little bit of exposure really went a long way for me. Overall, this was probably one of the best courses I've taken on Udemy and I am excited to explore future courses with Brad. His passion is clear while watching his videos which allows me to be passionate as well in the topics. It's also important to mention that Brad teaches good practices to use for HTML and CSS for your own future use and uses modern tools. It was SUCH a relief to see you use Visual Studio Code and show us all of the great plugins on it. I don't think I'll be using any other IDE's. Just a really fantastic course, I loved every second of it.

results.content:
Thorough course with many projects to follow, break and fix again - however I think that unguided projects would be useful too, as this is not a skill that can be taken forward without dedicated practice time. I myself have let this skill fall by the wayside on a previous course for this very reason. I simply relaxed after the course and then never returned to practice it - my own fault, but integrating practice exercises into the course would only be beneficial. 

A commendation from some dev guys on our team who also jumped on to certain sections of the course: Brad teaches best practice from the start through the use of variables, utility classes and so on. These are important to collaboration and efficiency and are usually learnt the hard way by most starting out. 

I would have pulled SCSS/SASS out of this course as I was rearing to get started the moment we'd finished up with the HTML and CSS. SCSS, whilst I can absolutely see the usefulness of it is something I'm going to put on the back burner until I'm entirely comfortable and practiced with the two foundation languages. That said, Brad has arranged the course in such a away that all work you do is setup for ease of reference post course and so I will simply cross that bridge when I'm comfortable to do so. 

This course is a long haul course, it's taken us (design team) around 4 months to complete with weekly time slots set alongside our full time jobs. Definitely worth it though. 

Cheers Brad, and thank you.

Cheers Brad, and thank you.

results.content:
I enjoyed the course to a certain extent. The teacher is good, however, I think several fundamental explanations on the logic behind HTML and CSS are missing. Which can confuse the beginners. 
I have found myself writing code randomly, while accompanying the classes, which wasn't explained by the teacher what it did.
I understand, that the logic behind the course serves also to please advanced developers on HTML & CSS. However, ultimately, the title of the course is addressed for complete beginners.
There are, without a doubt, better free resources online, which I have found way more complete and helpful, e.g. Front-end Master's free bootcamp, or even youtube tutorials.

results.content:
I like the way that this course structure. Every video is like a separate entity of their own. I have taken some course that likes to chain every video together, so when I want to go back to relearn any specific skills, I do not know where to start.

The pace of the instructor is good, not too fast and not too slow, I have fun coding along in this course. 

I think this course would be better if at the end of every section the instructor leaves me with some exercise, so I can repeat what I just learned. I know that I could just create an exercise by myself, but to have the exercise built-in with the course would be nice.

Overall, this is a great course for a starter or anyone who want to regain their knowledge in HTML/CSS. I recommend this course to everyone, it worth every money.

Bardzo dobrze poprowadzony kurs dla kompletnych nowicjuszy oraz tych trochę bardziej doświadczonych. 
Ja należę do tych drugich, więc kilka pierwszych sekcji przewinąłem, a z reszty uzyskałem odpowiedzi których szukałem, szczególnie jeżeli o chodzi o sass oraz flex/grid.
