results.content:
Probably because the course is not aimed at complete beginners sometimes I feel that things are going too fast for me. For instance I sense that understanding containers and have a plan for the page layout is one of the most critical aspects when creating a webpage yet I got really confused in places as to why this container goes under that container and why the third container goes over another container etc. So you have to stop the video in those cases and try to reverse engineer the logic because you don't understand why was this done in this particular way and whether there was another way this could have been done. Is the lecturer for instance following a certain framework when creating webpages? I think about the concepts that are most important and feel a bit overwhelmed at this point. Not sure how can I expand on my training and actually get good at designing webpages rather than following along something that I have no clue how it's been belt and how the layout has been thoughout and why.

I commonly now use the "Inspect" option for some webpages online to look at how they're structured and I'm just overwhelmed with the amount of divs and classes and scripts that the only takeway is - I know how much padding or margin is on this or that box - what that means on a more grander scale and why is that an important setting - I don't really know.

It gives you all the tools you need to start building websites in a practical and concise way, going straight into what you will need and giving a lot of extra information about good practices to follow and design concepts and ideas.

results.content: Simply a great course. Brad covers a lot of material, and walks you through each section with clear descriptions and good examples. The projects were fun and useful, and I never felt like I was doing something that was not going to help me later, like I've experienced in some other courses. He kept it fun and interesting! My only complaint is that there is a lack of "try it yourself" emphasis on projects. Of course, you can try them yourself, but I would have enjoyed pre-project videos that lay out what we are going to make, things to take note of, and maybe some hints. That said, overall a great course and I would highly recommend it to anybody interested in learning HTML and CSS!

results.content:
This course was great. There were very few issues with it, and it really helped me learn exactly what it promised. Even the few issues there are are easy to look past. I'd highly recommend this to anyone wishing to learn HTML.
Pros
- Brad knows how to teach. This course gave me a great grasp on HTML and CSS.
- The sections on deploying a website and Sass were some really great additions.
- Loved getting to work on projects rather than just learn concepts and practices.
- Definitely worth the cost.
Cons
- Could use some quizzes/tests. There's a couple sections that serve as this, which I really liked. There should definitely be more.
- The video editing could be better. There's times where he types the wrong thing, screwing up the viewer, and he goes back later to fix it after he realizes it. Editing could solve this issues.
- The section involving the Google Maps API needs to be fixed to re-accommodate  for updates. There's a few small things like here and there.
results.content_html:
This course was great. There were very few issues with it, and it really helped me learn exactly what it promised. Even the few issues there are are easy to look past. I'd highly recommend this to anyone wishing to learn HTML.
Pros
- Brad knows how to teach. This course gave me a great grasp on HTML and CSS.
- The sections on deploying a website and Sass were some really great additions.
- Loved getting to work on projects rather than just learn concepts and practices.
- Definitely worth the cost.
Cons
- Could use some quizzes/tests. There's a couple sections that serve as this, which I really liked. There should definitely be more.
- The video editing could be better. There's times where he types the wrong thing, screwing up the viewer, and he goes back later to fix it after he realizes it. Editing could solve this issues.
- The section involving the Google Maps API needs to be fixed to re-accommodate for updates. There's a few small things like here and there.

results.content:
I really enjoyed this course.  I have a strong programming background, but mainly in back-end and enterprise software.  This was a great course to really get a grasp on the basics of front-end development.  It filled in a lot of holes for me, but I think it would work just as well for somebody just starting out.

Brad was engaging, and showed that it's ok to make mistakes (and, how to fix them).

The only reasons I knocked half a start off the rating are: 
- I asked a question in the comments, but never received an answer.
- Like most courses I've taken with very smart people, there are times he gets click-happy.  He knows what he's doing, and types really fast and then moves on.  I needed to rewind a number of times just to catch up.  Again, this is definitely not a trait unique to this trainer, and it certainly isn't as glaring as other courses I've taken.

All in all, I was very happy with, and engaged in, this course (heck, I'm writing this review at 10:00 on a Friday night).  I would suggest it to anybody, and I'm probably going to see if there are additional courses Brad teaches that apply to me.
results.content_html:

Brad was engaging, and showed that it's ok to make mistakes (and, how to fix them).

The only reasons I knocked half a start off the rating are:
- I asked a question in the comments, but never received an answer.
- Like most courses I've taken with very smart people, there are times he gets click-happy. He knows what he's doing, and types really fast and then moves on. I needed to rewind a number of times just to catch up. Again, this is definitely not a trait unique to this trainer, and it certainly isn't as glaring as other courses I've taken.

All in all, I was very happy with, and engaged in, this course (heck, I'm writing this review at 10:00 on a Friday night). I would suggest it to anybody, and I'm probably going to see if there are additional courses Brad teaches that apply to me.

results.content:
I'm giving two stars because it's very apparent that Brad had good intentions as providing a breadth of knowledge (fitting a ton of topics into one course).

Having said that, Brad is just not skilled as a teacher. He is not effective at switching vantage points and entering into the mind of a student. The course was entitled "HTML & CSS from the beginning," yet he flew through the course/projects at warp speed. 

He did a very poor job providing understandable rationales. Once he "taught" a topic once, he assumed we understood it fully. Any good teacher knows that is a toxic mindset.

What is also infuriating is that Brad never answers questions, unlike other more skilled/friendly teachers. He plugged all of his social media accounts and told us "to follow him." But when i politely asked him questions on his accounts, he never replied.

Brad routinely had mistakes or typos in his code, which was the main impetus for me needing to ask him questions (and you can imagine how aggravating it is when he doesn't respond to questions, when they are pertaining to his typos).

In conclusion, I recognize Brad wanted to give us a wealth of knowledge, but 21 hours of content is way too much. He should have helped us refine our CSS skills, instead of injecting PHP & JavaScript, which were unnecessary.

I'm not requesting a refund because I did learn a lot, but my learning came more from taking my confusion from Brad and using Google.

results.content:
Brad is a skilled developer no doubt of that. Came here from his youtube channel to give a try to web dev (switched from C#). Some things could be left over or explained more (Jquery parts). Some things could be linked or mentioned in videos (cross-browser support) so I will only give 4.5 ... An author should always assume that students are dumb and will not search that at Google. BUT! Overall this course is really good and certainly will help grasp the basics of web page modelling (really well-explained flex and grid system) I would like to see more advanced but explained in "for-idiots style" course from you Brad. I will definitely look to your Bootstrap JS and React courses, they are for me better than Treehouse ones
PS: the hamburger menu using only CSS without JSS is DOPE

results.content: Brad outdid himself with this course. I've taken several HTML/CSS basic courses, you'd think I'd get it by now... Anyway, Brad had the patience to go into each detail in a clear and concise manner, which has to be a challenge for an experienced instructor to go over and over and still maintain your cool. It's important to note that the basic paradigm for building websites has shifted with the inclusion of Flex and Grid. Brad did a great job of blending together all the current technologies as if they were always there into useful projects anyone could use in their own work. Well done, Brad.

results.content: There is some content used that wasn't explained beforehand. For example, I saw the "nav" tag being used in this project, but we had never seen this before. Other than that, very good stuff. Word of advice for people who are learning: Watch the videos until you reach the project, then actually try and build the project yourself before watching the videos. This made me Google and learn stuff that wasn't covered in the videos in great detail. You'll also get to come up with solutions to problem you encounter, and then see Brad solve the problem his way.

results.content:
Already finished the course I must say it has everything (and more) I expected to learn about CSS. It's quite a lot and yet there is still a long way to become a master.  
Easy to understand (even at 1.25x speed), with projects that helps you repeat and learn the concepts and that may be real professional projects.
It's the second course I take from Brad and I'm really impressed of the quality, 5 stars totally deserved.  As the title said it's above my expectations.

As recommended in the last video, it's important to use what you've recently learned in the course by doing your own projects and practicing a lot to master css in this case.

As a suggestion, it may be a good idea to explain what you want to do first, challenge the student to do it him/herself and then show your solution. This could be valid for any course, Brad.  

Now I'll continue with the javascript course.

results.content:
This course is truly a 5 star course. For me, this is the course that got through my thick skull! A lightbulb moment! There's plenty of super helpful lessons for beginners and I would say it's especially good for those with a minimum level of experience with CSS. Before taking the course I really only understood how to use (copy & paste) bits and pieces of css to make minor markup edits to existing stylesheets. Now I feel confident I can properly markup the html and css from scratch for entire web pages and even add some interesting effects as well.

Before, my primary confusion with CSS was how to plan and organize, even a simple page of content. I could not quite grasp how to properly organize my css without creating a big mess, with too many unnecessary repeats of the same markup, again and again. Now I understand how to keep things simple by using variables and most importantly, how to best create and use Utility classes I can apply to all my projects. Also, from a practical standpoint, I now understand how and when to use Flexbox and/or Grid CSS. All of this is going to take my production level up a few notches for sure!

In addition, for me Brad is an outstanding instructor because he keeps things moving briskly and really hits home on the most important topics. Then he is consistent with his lessons, project after project. 

The only project I had problems with was the Hamburger Menu Overlay mini-project. It's just a lot of markup and although I completely understand the concepts, it was a bit much to take in so quickly. I'll come back to that one in a few months, after I have a few more projects under my best.

results.content:
I am a computer science student in silicon valley with two semesters left til i graduate. I am taking this course and Brads modern JS course to prepare for my desired career in front-end-dev/engineering. Being in CS I had the luxury of taking Web Dev as an elective, so, I went into this being pretty comfortable up to module 8 (the website projects are tough simply because it involves some design and such) however core html/css fundamentals i learned in class, so, I was able to move fast in one night to section 3..if you are like me an already know some web dev and want to prepare for a career in this, this course is for you! If you have 0 experience, definitely pay attention to section 1-3 but the course is geared towards you! Definitely entry level first and foremost. If you are a professional, this course will also serve you great. 

Brad is amazing and his courses all hold pure quality and effort. I 100% recommend this course to anyone considering it. The projects seem amazing! (This review was asked of me at the end of section 2...)

results.content:
Brad does an excellent job overall at teaching concepts in HTML + CSS. I had already gone through some other courses but felt this one left me much more knowledgeable overall, especially since you build so many projects. 

The main reasons I didn't give it a full 5 stars are:
-Brad does not cover naming conventions that you will likely see in actual working roles for large companies, such as the BEM naming convention. It's not overly difficult to learn BEM but it would have definitely been a smart addition to the course.

- There were a few times Brad coded something in a "suboptimal" way. He used jQuery for a smooth scroll effect despite the fact that CSS has a built-in smooth scroll effect that requires MUCH less code (it's literally a single line of code to do it in CSS). Other odd things included using absolute positioning for gradients rather than simply adding gradient divs that work far better and require less code. I frequently read the Q&A for each section because other commentors pointed little stuff like this out which I would have had no idea of -- would have been nice for Brad to include it.

In spite of those 2 gripes, this is by far the best intro to HTML/CSS course I have done and it absolutely sets you on a good path for web development.

results.content: This course is highly recommended! It's clear that Brad is a professional instructor. He is guiding you steadily through the classes and starts from a beginner's point of view with tips and tricks on how to code faster and more efficiently- organization is key, you don't want your code to be a mess. He included his choice of code editor- Visual Studio Code which I found really useful (I was using another one before) You can find information on how to build websites online but you won't find Brad's work ethic and clear instructions- all in one package. Favorite part for me was the projects, I gave myself plenty of time to finish them on my own and added customizations, I suggest you do the same, challenge yourself to do it slightly different than the instructor and you will be amazed by your progress! Good luck!

results.content:
Really good course that gives you an excellent foundation into learning web development. 

This course has been partly responsible for getting me my first job in the front-end field and I can't thank Brad enough for that. 

If I was to have one thing to improve it would be the UI of some of the sandbox items, it is really painful to look at should you need to keep going back. A few more challenges would have been nice but overall highly recommended!
